title: Walking the Web of Concept-Class Relationships in Incrementally Trained Interpretable Models
author: Susmit Agrawal (Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad), Deepika Vemuri (Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad), Sri Siddarth Chakaravarthy P (Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad), Vineeth N. Balasubramanian (Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad), ...
relevance_why: The paper discusses concept-based models which can be relevant to audio-language modeling for enhancing interpretability through multimodal approaches, potentially informing methods for audio-captioning tasks in Haohe Liu's research.
background: The task is to develop a model that can incrementally learn new classes while preserving relationships with previously learned classes in a meaningful and interpretable way.
contribution: This paper introduces the MuCIL model, which utilizes multimodal concepts to handle incremental learning efficiently, achieving state-of-the-art classification performance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior methods either assume static concept sets or completely independent concept sets for each experience, making them less practical in dynamic scenarios.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work uniquely integrates multimodal embeddings without increasing trainable parameters, enabling adaptation to novel concepts while maintaining existing relationships.

key_innovation: Leveraging both visual and textual embeddings to create a flexible and interpretable framework for continuous learning.
real_world_impact: The approach can improve the adaptability of AI systems in real-world applications by enabling them to learn and interpret new data dynamically, crucial for fields like autonomous systems and interactive AI.
limitations: The current model’s ability to interpret complex relationships might still require validation in diverse settings beyond the benchmark datasets.

new_terms.concept-class relationships: **Concept-class relationships** refer to the associations between learned concepts and the categories they represent in a model, which are crucial for interpretability and incremental learning.
